Comment: I don't know. I try not to think too deeply about it because right now i have to worry about what we're going to do. My husband is a trucker and as loads dry up he's likely going to lose his job. Things have already slowed way down. We depend on his income. We need his job for medical insurance. And we're trying to build a stock of basic survival stuff since our country is getting cut off from trade. We're now staring down the barrell of empty shelves within a few weeks, and it's going to be long term. And i'm in hurricane alley so as summer approaches, that's on all our minds too. This regime has severed access to disaster aid so.. then what? It's all horrifying. And now we're losing a long standing relationship with our northern neighbors. During my time living in washington and montana, canadians were the nicest and most lovely people i met. Y'all are unlikely to ever trust us again. It's crushing.
Author: ThrowAwayGarbage82

Comment: I don‚Äôt harbour ill-will towards average Americans. I have many American friends; it‚Äôs the subset of your population that supports the current regime even after the constant blunders that almost seems ‚Äúalien‚Äù to me. To be so callous to the rest of the world and to view allies as ‚Äúlands to be conquered or taxed‚Äù while being the same nation that claims rejection of all imperialism under a tyrant‚Ä¶ the hypocrisy just boggles my mind; I can never listen to the ‚ÄúStar Spangled Banner‚Äù again (the only anthem other than mine that I know word-for-word) without rolling my eyes to the back of my skull due to the emptiness of the message behind the lyrics.    It‚Äôs just more heartbreaking than anything for most Canadians; we used to look up to you, many Canadians won‚Äôt admit it but it‚Äôs true that nobody held America in a higher regard than Canada; it‚Äôs sad to see it shattered.
Author: FunBanned
